segment.source: Clearly identify the issue or the user's objective in the first line of the dialog's text.
segment.target: Clearly identify the issue or the user's objective in the first line of the dialog's text.

segment.source: The dialog title is the main instruction and is optional.
segment.target: The dialog title is the main instruction and is optional.

segment.source: Use a short title to explain what people need to do with the dialog.
segment.target: Use a short title to explain what people need to do with the dialog.

segment.source: Long titles do not wrap and are truncated.
segment.target: Long titles do not wrap and are truncated.

segment.source: If you're using the dialog to deliver a simple message, error or question, you can optionally omit the title.
segment.target: If you're using the dialog to deliver a simple message, error or question, you can optionally omit the title.

segment.source: Rely on the content text to deliver that core information.
segment.target: Rely on the content text to deliver that core information.

segment.source: Make sure that the title relates directly to the button choices.
segment.target: Make sure that the title relates directly to the button choices.

segment.source: The dialog content contains the descriptive text and is required.
segment.target: The dialog content contains the descriptive text and is required.

segment.source: Present the message, error, or blocking question as simply as possible.
segment.target: Present the message, error, or blocking question as simply as possible.

segment.source: If a dialog title is used, use the content area to provide more detail or define terminology.
segment.target: If a dialog title is used, use the content area to provide more detail or define terminology.

segment.source: Don't repeat the title with slightly different wording.
segment.target: Don't repeat the title with slightly different wording.

segment.source: At least one dialog button must appear.
segment.target: At least one dialog button must appear.

segment.source: Use buttons with text that identifies specific responses to the main instruction or content.
segment.target: Use buttons with text that identifies specific responses to the main instruction or content.

segment.source: An example is, "Do you want to allow AppName to access your location?", followed by "Allow" and "Block" buttons.
segment.target: An example is, "Do you want to allow AppName to access your location?", followed by "Allow" and "Block" buttons.

segment.source: Specific responses can be understood more quickly, resulting in efficient decision making.
segment.target: Specific responses can be understood more quickly, resulting in efficient decision making.

segment.source: Error dialogs display the error message in the dialog box, along with any pertinent information.
segment.target: Error dialogs display the error message in the dialog box, along with any pertinent information.

segment.source: The only button used in an error dialog should be “Close” or a similar action.
segment.target: The only button used in an error dialog should be “Close” or a similar action.

segment.source: Don't use dialogs for errors that are contextual to a specific place on the page, such as validation errors (in password fields, for example), use the app's canvas itself to show inline errors.
segment.target: Don't use dialogs for errors that are contextual to a specific place on the page, such as validation errors (in password fields, for example), use the app's canvas itself to show inline errors.
